case_title: GUL MUHAMMAD vs THE ASSISTANT COLLECTOR, CENTRAL EXCISE AND LAND CUSTOMS AND 2 Other
respondant: The Assistant Collector, Central Excise and Land Customs
Collector, Central Excise and Land Customs
Joint Secretary (Customs), Finance Department, Government of Pakistan

accussed_details.name: Gul Muhammad
allegation: Possession of a car imported into Pakistan without payment of customs duty
Violation of clauses (8), (9), (89), and (90) of Table to section 156(1) of the Customs Act (IV of 1969)

complaint_summary: Petitioner sought release of a car confiscated by customs authorities, alleging improper seizure and non-compliance with statutory notice requirements under section 180 of the Customs Act.
investigation_summary: Customs authorities detained the car on 5-6-1974 for verification of documents and formally seized it on 14-11-1974. Subsequent notices and hearings led to the confiscation of the car and imposition of a Rs. 5,000 penalty, later waived upon appeal.
judgment_summary: The court dismissed the petition, holding that the petitioner failed to establish lawful importation of the car and payment of customs duty. The court declined to issue a writ under Article 199 of the Constitution, citing discretionary jurisdiction and the petitioner's obligation to pay government dues.
Decision_or_verdict: Petition dismissed; car subject to payment of customs duty and government dues.
legal_arguments: Petitioner argued improper seizure under section 168(1) and failure to serve notice under section 180 within two months.
Respondents contended the car was detained for verification on 5-6-1974 and formally seized on 14-11-1974, with notice served within statutory limits.
Court held petitioner liable for customs duty under section 18 and dismissed claims for unconditional release of the car.

details.status: Confiscated; subject to payment of customs duty

sections: Section 31 of Imports and Exports (Control) Act, 1950
key_issues: Whether the seizure of the car complied with statutory requirements under the Customs Act.
Whether the petitioner was liable for payment of customs duty and government dues.

legal_terms.Seizure: Taking possession of goods by authorities for legal violations.

words_and_phrases.Detention: Temporary holding of goods for verification.
words_and_phrases.Confiscation: Permanent seizure of goods for legal violations.

summary_vector_notes: Petitioner challenged the confiscation of a car under Customs Act provisions, alleging improper seizure and notice delays. Court dismissed the petition, emphasizing the petitioner's liability for customs duty and discretionary jurisdiction under Article 199.

contraventions: Clauses (8) and (89) of Table to Section 156(1) of Customs Act (IV of 1969)

petitioner.claim: Car seized on 1974-06-05 under Section 168(1) of Customs Act; mandatory notice under Section 180 not served within two months; car should be returned without payment of customs duty.

respondents.claim: Car detained for verification on 1974-06-05; formal seizure occurred on 1974-11-14; notice served within statutory period; customs duty and dues must be paid.

court_findings.mandatory_notice: Not served within two months as per Section 168(2)
court_findings.import_violation: Car imported without permit, violating Section 31 of Imports and Exports Act and Customs Act clauses (8), (9), (89), and (90).
court_findings.burden_of_proof: Petitioner failed to prove lawful import and payment of customs duty.

decision.reasoning: Petitioner liable for customs duty and government dues; discretionary jurisdiction under Article 199 cannot favor possession of ill-gotten gains.
decision.relief: No effective relief granted; petition dismissed.
